Well the truck was in a massive car-park/parking lot outside a supermarket and dominos on the edge of a town, certainly not rural.

Where I live and where this truck is located most of the roads are more than adequate to accommodate an F150. But yeah I mean having Redneck and the confederate flag plastered across your tailgate definitely turns heads. However a fair number of people out in the country have these American trucks as they #8217;re better for a lot of things!

Well fuel is expensive especially compared to the US at roughly $5 per gallon, some people convert them from gasoline to LPG (liquid petroleum gas) to save which brings the price to more in line with the US. Parts etc are probably more expensive but there are quite a few of these trucks around so possibly not too bad.

The amount of amazing people that helped me out and gave me advice while I was driving through the Mojave in an #8216;07 grand caravan made me love the states even more than I already did and after that it felt like home.

Live in East Sussex, UK but drove over 12,000 miles across the Western half of the US last year. Out in States like Utah and Nevada the roads are very different at home, wider, straighter and amazingly for such a low-population density area, better maintained than where I #8217;m from. I found after the first few hours driving was less stressful and somewhat #8220;easier #8221; than at home. However there are areas in the UK with wider straighter roads that where I live, such as East Anglia.

WRITING.TITLE: Have you visited anywhere in the UK outside of London, and if so what did you think?

WRITING.TEXT: That #8217;s super interesting, I definitely agree about the roads and buildings etc, having spent a fair bit of time in Europe, I would definitely say the UK is more similar to North America than Europe. I travelled the US for a while and found a lot of landscapes and customs to be reminiscent of home, whereas when in Europe I tend to feel homesick quite quickly.
I used to live in Springfield (a suburb of Milton Keynes)! What do you think of MK? I always thought of it as a British version of an American town haha! *edit (words)
You #8217;re probably one of the first people I #8217;ve heard say they like Birmingham, sure you #8217;re not talking about Alabama haha!
That #8217;s cool, Canterbury is a pretty nice place, the Cathedral is beautiful! It #8217;s an old place even by British standards.

Yeah the South East doesn #8217;t really have much of the #8220;open range #8221; feel as it #8217;s the most #8220;desirable #8221; place to live and the most densely populated due to being close to London. If you head out to the plains in East Anglia and Lincolnshire you #8217;d probably feel less enclosed!
That #8217;s awesome, glad you enjoyed your time there. You #8217;ve seen more of the country than I have!

That #8217;s hilarious, some people don #8217;t like to find out they #8217;re wrong I guess, glad you liked the city though, I #8217;ve never been but hope to one day! Also I greatly appreciate the Peep Show reference, didn #8217;t know that made it across the pond haha!
Oh it will, it #8217;s just it #8217;ll be the government doing the watching!

Haha absolutely, love the map by the way! It #8217;s just there are a lot more places like [this](https://goo.gl/maps/6V4mBcRp4F1Dm1Qj8) than in the South East. Sure you #8217;ll see more traffic and houses and pass through more towns but you can also drive for 250-300 miles of scenery like this, that I #8217;ve always found reminiscent of the great plains in the US and Canada albeit on a smaller scale!

That #8217;s super interesting, I love California and was lucky enough to spend a month of my time in the US driving from LA all the way up til I blew through the border with Oregon! As to your question, nope it #8217;s a two-way county #8220;A #8221; road, in the UK lanes are separated by white lines like in the photo, whereas yellow lines are used to denote no-parking zones at the sides of roads and intersections. I much prefer the US method of road markings however as it makes it much more obvious where you shouldn #8217;t cross lanes! *edit (formatting)
That #8217;s awesome (in the literal sense of the word). Believe it or not I live in the next county over (East Sussex) and I #8217;ve never been. Now I feel bad.
Ayyy Sussex represent!
Haha looks like it!

For sure you can still get some decent ideas out of a controlled economy, but I #8217;m afraid it #8217;s literally fact that free market competition is what drives people to create better, more interesting and ultimately more successful things. If no one were to profit from the sale of games they would have come out with RCT and left it there. I mean what #8217;s the point of making a sequel or even a wholly new better game if no ones going to make anything from it?
I #8217;m not saying that it #8217;s just the way I thought to put it.

Soccer and golf are literally some of the most commercialized activities on the planet. That fits my example perfectly. Sure they may have been invented by people who had no plan to make money from them. Capitalism is the entire reason you can play golf in the desert or have people like Messi or Ronaldo inspiring kids around the world to play. Like I said, sure a closed market system can invent something but you #8217;re not going to find a socialist country building beautifully designed golf courses and clubhouses, or making better more precise clubs etc, you #8217;re just not. And if they did, it would only be the oligarchs and political elite using them.
Yeah I #8217;d imagine it switches year on year between a few Sussex beach towns. Eastbourne calls itself the Sunshine Coast after all!
I love Norfolk, it #8217;s a beautiful place and is large and diverse. I #8217;m a pick-up truck, country pub, big sky, Sunday BBQ kind of guy so it #8217;s right up my street.

I don #8217;t have other people work for me but I work for myself and have the freedom to do so. I am the arbiter of whether I live an enjoyable life doing what I want rather than the government telling me to. As for what #8217;s wrong with bikes and no fancy clubhouses, nothing, in and of itself. However having people starving and pedalling themselves to the rice-fields, on rusty worn out bikes that they #8217;ll never have the means to improve, while a parade of DPRK statesmen and officials blow past them in limousines, smoking cigars and eating cheese and caviar, without giving a rats ass about them is a problem. See the difference between capitalism and communism is that you #8217;ll always get people like that no matter where you are, however in a free market people have the opportunity to do better, work hard and make a life for themselves without the government siphoning off all their money to spend on cars, food, drugs, resorts etc that the people who paid for it will never have the opportunity to enjoy. You cannot escape corruption, and that #8217;s the problem, communism only truly works and is fair in a world free from corruption, and that world does not and will never exist.

It #8217;s literally not propaganda though, I enjoy doing better than other people. I have a strong drive to work, achieve and do better, there are people who are happy doing the minimal and taking handouts. I #8217;m happy in a system where I get what I give and you get yours. I don #8217;t have to study to understand that that #8217;s better, if I #8217;m missing some massive part of communism where it #8217;s more everyone gets a life they desire, doing what they want and less potato eaters and off to the gulag then please enlighten me!
Well that #8217;s a surprisingly vindictive end to what was otherwise an interesting, civil and potentially fruitful discussion. Oh well dude, enjoy your life #9996; #65039;
Talk about taking the good with the bad!! Amazing!
Well if Communism does win, shit and hair will probably be on the menu. But considering the current state of your cause, it won #8217;t. Enjoy living in the hell that is capitalism lol.
Our county town of Lewes hosts the largest bonfire night celebration in Europe so I #8217;d say so!
Suffolk and Swansea!
I forgot to mention that Banoffi Pie is an East Sussex export! It was invented at The Hungry Monk in Jevington, E Sx.

I mean bonfire nights, and bonfire societies. That sure is a big bonfire pile but at the Lewes Bonfire night in East Sussex you get 80,000 people marching through the streets with burning crosses and rockets while 25-30 different local bonfire societies let off thousands of fireworks as bands, dancers and fire breathers march through the tight streets. Look [here](https://images.app.goo.gl/5hXaxJ3VxUTp6RCw8) and [here](https://images.app.goo.gl/xPTVa7cRQTZD5pibA).

To be honest it #8217;s usually so crowded you can barely move and every 5 seconds you #8217;ll have a rocket fly inches past your face that some kid has let off, it #8217;s better after a couple tins. However there are some slightly smaller but equally impressive ones, largely due to [Sussex Bonfire Traditon](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sussex_Bonfire_Societies)
Yeah, bonfire night is one day where health and safety well and truly goes out the window in Sussex!
Haha I #8217;m sure there are scarier beasts lurking in Indiana!

WRITING.TITLE: #8220;Tripping #8221; or extreme hallucinations during hypoglycaemic attack?
WRITING.TEXT: Hi all, I am a type-1 diabetic with good control and luckily no issues other than the diabetes to speak of. However one aspect of my experience with diabetes is one that I never hear people talking about or discussing ever: When I have a severe hypoglycaemic attack ie during the night, I often get extreme and terrifying hallucinations including time dilation, malevolent entities, feelings of being thrown around the room, existential dread etc. Some of these episodes have been so exquisitely mortifying that Ive has flashbacks and moments of panic when I remember that I may return to those depths of anguish through no fault of my own again. In one particularly dreadful incident I woke up in the middle of the night dripping in sweat and on my own, proceeded to descend into what I can only describe as a pit of existential terror, where time no longer had meaning, I was convinced that I was stuck in an infinitely regressing time loop, watched over by terrifying demons, my bedroom was no longer a familiar place and I remember screaming in primal fear that I would never be able to return to a normal state. I then proceeded to enter my bathroom and fall headfirst into the shower cubicle in an attempt to get out of the horrendous state I was in. I woke up in hospital, back in the real world and the feeling of relief was indescribable. The experience is almost identical to how I #8217;ve seen people describe bad LSD/DMT trips. So diabetic friends, have any of you experienced hypoglycaemic trips like this and if so I #8217;d love to hear about them. Look after yourselves guys! TLDR: Occasionally when my sugar-levels drop very low I experience haunting, mind mending hallucinations and time dilation. Anyone else?

I know exactly what you mean about the teleportation thing, I #8217;ve definitely had that before, you can #8217;t feel your legs walking to it feels almost like you #8217;re hovering along ugh gross. Glad to know I #8217;m not the only one out there who gets those weird hallucinations occasionally!
K

The drive out there is honestly one of the most beautiful experiences of my life, cruising up the Sea to Sky highway through Squamish and Whistler and then North East through Jasper and some of the most awe-inspiring scenery you could ever imagine. Enjoy dude.

Sometimes it hasn #8217;t even been that low, often I #8217;ll receive help from my girlfriend and obviously at that point she #8217;s not so concerned with testing my levels at that time but once I #8217;m back in the land of the living I #8217;ll test and I #8217;ve never seen it lower than around 2.3ish but has been as high as 3.5, only 5 mins after coming out of the hypoglycaemic abyss!
Wow, that #8217;s beautiful. Was super surprised to see UK in the title!
